docs.lead_paragraph: The House is expected to vote today on two versions of health-care reform -- a sensible if limited Democratic bill and a harmful Republican version. The Democrats have also embraced a bipartisan bill now pending in the Senate that would make it easier for workers who lose their jobs to buy health coverage. That is of critical importance in this era of downsizing and job shifts. House Republicans have embraced these provisions but have added to their bill amendments that are not only bad health policy but could delay passage of any useful health-care reform this year. The Senate bill, written by Nancy Kassebaum and Ted Kennedy, would require insurance companies to sell policies to workers who leave their jobs but have been continuously covered by their employers. The bill would also limit the length of time that insurers could refuse to cover an applicant's pre-existing medical problem and forbid insurers to drop chronically ill enrollees.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Gay Marriage, an Oxymoron" (Op-Ed, March 23): My husband and I have been married for 50 years. Our commitment to each other has been based solely on our love and the joy in raising our children. Neither the church nor the state can influence such a relationship.

headline.main: Society Can Accept Gay Marriages, Too;Not an Obstacle

headline.main: Keep Blue Cross Conversion in Public Eye

docs.lead_paragraph: New York State lawmakers agreed today to require insurers to pay for at least 48 hours of hospital care for mothers and newborns. Barring any last-minute problems, the agreement by a joint legislative committee would place New York on a growing list of states that have adopted or are considering laws requiring insurers to pay for a second day in a hospital for childbirth. Gov. George E. Pataki has said that he also supports the idea of providing an extra day of care to new mothers who request it.

headline.main: Accord on Longer Maternity Hospital Stays

headline.main: Keep Blue Cross Conversion in Public Eye;Reimburse Hospitals

docs.lead_paragraph: National banks won an important Supreme Court victory today with a unanimous ruling that the banks may sell insurance from branch offices in small towns, despite state laws to the contrary. The decision, a setback for the insurance industry, was the latest of several Supreme Court rulings to endorse the broad view of national banks' powers held by the office of the Comptroller of the Currency. In an important decision last year, the Court upheld the Comptroller's policy of permitting national banks to sell annuities.

headline.main: Ruling Backs Banks' Sales Of Insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Government today issued rules restricting the ability of health maintenance organizations to pay bonuses and other financial rewards to doctors as an inducement to limit the services provided to elderly patients and poor people under Medicare and Medicaid. The rules, the first of their kind, are intended to protect patients who might otherwise have difficulty getting medically necessary services, Federal officials said.

headline.main: U.S. Issues Rules for H.M.O.'s In an Effort to Protect Patients

docs.lead_paragraph: It was hard enough for members of Congress to make laws when they had to get them through the House, the Senate and the White House. These days they have to worry about the Electoral College, too. With the Senate majority leader as the presumptive Republican Presidential candidate and the Speaker of the House pledging support, the Congressional part of the law-making agenda is as political as it has ever been. And the Presidential part is as political as it always is in a year divisible by four.

docs.lead_paragraph: Partners for Seniors has expanded its pharmacy benefit!" a newspaper ad proclaims to Tucson's big retirement community. "Enjoy free health club benefits," promises Intergroup of Arizona. "Do you know," touts FHP Health Care, "how your health plan stacks up against FHP's? You tell us. $0 plan premium. $0 deductibles." Tucson's health maintenance organizations offer free hospital stays, free annual physical exams, free X-rays, free mammograms, free laboratory tests, $26 eyeglasses, $5 and $10 doctors' appointments, free rides to get to them and this year's newest offering: $7 for a three-month supply of any of 300 prescription drugs.

headline.main: Tucson H.M.O.'s May Offer Model for Medicare's Future

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to put pressure on the state to come up with a plan to pay for hospital care for the poor, the heads of several New Jersey hospitals today left a $96 million bill on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's desk and vowed to begin doing business with only those companies providing health insurance for their employees. Since Jan. 1, Governor Whitman and the State Legislature have been unable to agree on a new financing plan to repay 84 acute-care hospitals for the estimated $384 million in charity care that they provide each year.

headline.main: Seeking Indigent-Care Plan, Hospitals Send Trenton Bill
